results.title: Tiny Forests With Big Benefits
results.abstract: Native plants crowded onto postage-stamp-size plots have been delivering environmental benefits around the world — and, increasingly, in the U.S.

media.caption: A Miyawaki Forest in Danehy Park, near Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass.

results.title: Isabel Crook, 107, Dies; Her Life in China Spanned a Century of Change
results.abstract: A noted educator and anthropologist, she spent almost her entire life in China, where she was a committed friend of the Communist government.

media.caption: Isabel Crook in 1940, when she was Isabel Brown. Her life in China spanned the Japanese invasion and World War II, as well as the subsequent Communist revolution.

results.title: The Eternal Search for the ‘Nemesis Bird’
results.abstract: For every devoted birder, there is a bird that continues to elude sighting.

media.caption: A male Congo peafowl, a “nemesis bird” that the world-class birder Peter Kaestner has sought for decades.

results.adx_keywords: Movies;Pets;Dogs;Great Britain;London (England)
results.title: At This Movie, Their Phones Won’t Bother You. Their Barking Might.
results.abstract: A cinema chain in Britain is welcoming dogs to select screenings. They don’t need their own tickets, and they don’t need to turn off their cellphones.

media.caption: Damian and Catriona Spandley, with their dogs Lucky and Jeff, attending a screening of the movie “Strays” at the Curzon Aldgate cinema in London on Saturday. Mr. Spandley is a Curzon employee.
media.copyright: Mary Turner for The New York Times

results.title: A Speck of Old Iceland in Ice-Cold Lake Michigan
results.abstract: You can still find traces of Nordic history in the trails and trees of tiny Washington Island, Wis. And take a dip while you’re there — if you dare.

media.caption: Schoolhouse Beach, on Washington Island, Wis., is covered with smooth white stones, many of them stacked in cairns. The water of Lake Michigan, even in the summer, can still be chilly.
media.copyright: Narayan Mahon for The New York Times

results.title: The New Little Havana: Why Cuban Migrants Are Moving to Kentucky
results.abstract: Louisville, best known for bourbon, the Kentucky Derby and Muhammad Ali, is now home to the fastest-growing Cuban community in the country.

media.caption: Cubans began trickling into Jefferson County in 1995, after the Clinton administration and the Castro government signed an accord to allow 20,000 Cubans annually into the United States through a lottery.
